question: Which of the following is/are parts of a Markov decision process?
options: A set of possible rewards.
A set of possible states.
A set of possible starting positions.
A set of possible actions.
correctAnswer: A set of possible states.
A set of possible actions.

question: Assume you have a sequence of 10 elements, and each element has 4 features. Further assume that you have a standard, single-layer RNN with a hidden state size of 5. What is the size of the first RNN output?
What is the general data flow through an RNN language model?
options: input -> encoder -> decoder -> RNN
input -> decoder -> RNN -> encoder
input -> RNN -> encoder -> decoder
input -> encoder -> RNN -> decoder
correctAnswer: input -> encoder -> RNN -> decoder

question: Which of the following statements is/are true about protein folding?
options: The number of possible ways to fold is extremely high.
The protein folding problem deals with deriving the 3D structure from the amino acid sequence.
An amino acid sequence can be folded in exactly one way.
High throughput folding is about experimentally determining the 3D structure.
correctAnswer: The protein folding problem deals with deriving the 3D structure from the amino acid sequence.
The number of possible ways to fold is extremely high.

question: The 3D structure of a molecule ...
options: ... is unambiguously determined by a molecular graph.
... is ambiguously determined by a molecular graph.
... is straightforward to predict if the sequence of atoms is known.
... determines the functionality to a high degree.
correctAnswer: ... determines the functionality to a high degree.
... is ambiguously determined by a molecular graph.

question: A non-convex function ...
options: ... is rare in deep learning.
... does not have an analytical solution (i.e., can be directly calculated) for computing its minimum.
... always has a non-closed-form solution for a minimization problem.
... has an analytical solution (i.e., can be directly calculated) for computing its minimum.
correctAnswer: ... does not have an analytical solution (i.e., can be directly calculated) for computing its minimum.
... always has a non-closed-form solution for a minimization problem.

question: Which of the following statements is/are true about the ReLU activation function?
options: ReLUs can mitigate the vanishing gradient problem.
For positive inputs, ReLU equates to 1.
For negative inputs, ReLU equates to the identity function.
ReLU is computationally expensive.
correctAnswer: ReLUs can mitigate the vanishing gradient problem.

question: Which of the following statements is/are true about gradient descent?
options: It is an iterative method.
The initial starting value of a parameter must already be close to a minimum.
It will always converge to the global minimum.
The learning rate influences how much the value of a parameter changes.
correctAnswer: It is an iterative method.
The learning rate influences how much the value of a parameter changes.

question: Back-propagation through time ...
options: ... is the most common way to train an RNN.
... is the cause of vanishing gradients in RNNs.
... generates (potentially) very deep networks.
... is the cause of exploding gradients in RNNs.
correctAnswer: ... is the most common way to train an RNN.
... generates (potentially) very deep networks.

question: Drug discovery ...
options: ... always results in an approved drug.
... is about finding molecules that act on targets.
... can take many years.
... is an extremely expensive process.
correctAnswer: ... is about finding molecules that act on targets.
... is an extremely expensive process.
... can take many years.

question: Which of the following statements is/are true about data augmentation?
options: It is useful to artificially create more samples.
Not every augmentation technique is useful in every scenario.
It can potentially have a negative impact on the model performance.
It can increase data variation.
correctAnswer: It is useful to artificially create more samples.
It can increase data variation.
Not every augmentation technique is useful in every scenario.
It can potentially have a negative impact on the model performance.

question: In the context of language models, which statements is/are true about an embedding?
options: The decoder part of a language model is closely related to a word embedding.
An embedding contains the frequency of a word occurring in a text corpus.
Elements in a word embedding can potentially have a (strong) relationship/correlation with each other.
An embedding is a compact string representation of words.
correctAnswer: Elements in a word embedding can potentially have a (strong) relationship/correlation with each other.

question: Which of the following statements is/are true about sequence data?
options: Sequence data can only be used in supervised learning scenarios.
Every data can theoretically be represented as a sequence.
Typically, there is some sort of order in the data (time, position, etc.).
In terms of choosing machine learning models, it does not matter whether the data is a sequence or not.
correctAnswer: Every data can theoretically be represented as a sequence.
Typically, there is some sort of order in the data (time, position, etc.).

question: Consider the update function used during Q-learning: Q(sts ar) Â« (1 - a) * Q(Sy, a) ta * (r+ y * MaXa.s Q(Sts1> Atir)). Which of the following statements is/are true?
options: y is the learning rate.
@< a < 1 means that both the old Q-value as well as the new information will be used in the update step.
y = 1 means that the immediate reward is ignored.
a is the discount rate.
correctAnswer: @ < a < 1 means that both the old Q-value as well as the new information will be used in the update step.

question: Max-pooling ...
options: ... is common in convolutional neural networks.
... may decrease the spatial size of the data.
... is a form of subsampling.
... can reduce the computational load and memory requirements.
correctAnswer: ... is a form of subsampling.
... can reduce the computational load and memory requirements.
... may decrease the spatial size of the data.
... is common in convolutional neural networks.

question: Assume a language modeling scenario where you have a dictionary size of 1500, an embedding size of 100 and a hidden representation size of 200. What is the output size of the language model when considering a single input (one word)?
Which of the following statements is/are true about the weights of an RNN?
options: For each timestep, a dedicated weight matrix is used.
For sequences of different length, multiple (shared) weight matrices must be learned (one for each unique sequence length).
The longer the sequence, the bigger the weight matrix.
For each timestep, the same (shared) weight matrix is used.
correctAnswer: For each timestep, the same (shared) weight matrix is used.

question: Which of the following statements is/are true about text generation with language models?
options: Sampling can be performed on the predicted output probability distribution.
Given a starting word, always choosing the next word with the highest predicted probability will always yield the same generated text.
The same input will always lead to the same generated text.
The language model needs to be retrained if a different starting word is chosen.
correctAnswer: Given a starting word, always choosing the next word with the highest predicted probability will always yield the same generated text.
Sampling can be performed on the predicted output probability distribution.

question: Assume a reinforcement learning scenario with a 2-dimensional location grid of size 4x4. Further assume that a robot (the agent) is placed randomly on this grid and must move to the target destination, which is also somewhere random on this grid. There are 4 possible movements: up, down, left and right (if the robot tries to go off the grid, it remains at the same location). Each action has a reward of -1 (negative reward). If the robot reaches the target, +10 is awarded (positive reward). Which of the following statements is/are true?
options: There exists no policy that always gives an aggregated positive reward for every possible starting state.
The maximum number of steps of any policy is 4*4*4 = 64.
The maximum number of steps of an optimal policy is 6.
The minimum number of steps of an optimal policy is 0.
correctAnswer: The maximum number of steps of an optimal policy is 6.
The minimum number of steps of an optimal policy is 0.

question: In a Markov decision process, ...
options: ... rewards can be 0.
... the next action depends on all previous states.
... rewards can be negative.
... the next state depends on the agent's action and all previous states.
correctAnswer: ... rewards can be negative.
... rewards can be 0.

question: Assume a language modeling scenario where you have a dictionary size of 1000, an embedding size of 150 and a hidden representation size of 150. Which of the following statements is/are true when considering a single model input (one word)?
options: The model output are probabilities for each of the 1000 possible words.
The maximum input sequence length is 150.
The encoder and decoder matrices have equally many parameters.
The word embedding matrix is identical to the encoder matrix.
correctAnswer: The word embedding matrix is identical to the encoder matrix.
The encoder and decoder matrices have equally many parameters.
The model output are probabilities for each of the 1000 possible words.

question: In classification, ...
options: ... the target value is a class label.
... the target cannot be a number.
... we are dealing with an unsupervised machine learning scenario.
... we are dealing with a supervised machine learning scenario.
correctAnswer: ... the target value is a class label.
... we are dealing with a supervised machine learning scenario.

question: With respect to the vanishing gradient problem, which of the following statements is/are true regarding deep neural networks?
options: The vanishing gradient problem is independent of the network depth.
By increasing the network depth, the vanishing gradient problem can be mitigated.
Deep networks will always suffer from the vanishing gradient problem.
The deeper the network, the more multiplications (chain rule) we have to perform in the backward pass.
correctAnswer: The deeper the network, the more multiplications (chain rule) we have to perform in the backward pass.

question: Which of the following statements is/are true about SMILES (Simplified Molecular Input Line Entry Specification)?
options: It is a sequence representation of a molecule.
A molecular graph can be transformed into a SMILES string and the other way around.
A molecule can have different SMILES strings.
A molecule can only have exactly one SMILES string.
correctAnswer: It is a sequence representation of a molecule.
A molecule can have different SMILES strings.
A molecular graph can be transformed into a SMILES string and the other way around.

question: Which of the following statements is/are true about the vanishing gradient problem?
options: Repeated multiplication of gradients bigger than 1 leads to an vanishing gradient.
A vanishing gradient can be avoided by decreasing the learning rate.
Repeated multiplication of gradients smaller than 1 leads to a vanishing gradient.
A vanishing gradient can be avoided by increasing the learning rate.
correctAnswer: Repeated multiplication of gradients smaller than 1 leads to a vanishing gradient.

question: Which of the following statements is/are true about QSAR (Quantitative Structure-Activity Relationship)?
options: The hypothesis is that similar molecular structures have similar activities.
The molecule structure is determined by the bioactivity.
The hypothesis is that similar activities have similar molecular structures.
The bioactivity is determined by the molecule structure.
correctAnswer: The bioactivity is determined by the molecule structure.
The hypothesis is that similar molecular structures have similar activities.

question: In the forward pass of a neural network, the input vector is ...
options: ... passed through an element-wise non-linearity, added to bias weights and multiplied by a weight matrix.
... passed through an element-wise non-linearity, multiplied by a weight matrix and added to bias weights.
... added to bias weights, multiplied by a weight matrix and passed through an element-wise non-linearity.
... multiplied by a weight matrix, added to bias weights and passed through an element-wise non-linearity.
correctAnswer: ... multiplied by a weight matrix, added to bias weights and passed through an element-wise non-linearity.

question: In convolutional neural networks, which of the following statements is/are true about weight sharing?
options: It is about applying the kernel to one specific image position while keeping the weights the same.
It is about applying the kernel to one specific image position while continuously updating the weights.
It is about applying the kernel to all image positions while keeping the weights the same.
It is about applying the kernel to all image positions while continuously updating the weights.
correctAnswer: It is about applying the kernel to all image positions while keeping the weights the same.

question: The convolution of a 8x8 image with 1 feature map (channel) with 2 kernels of size 4x4 produces ...
options: an output with 2 feature maps.
an output with 4x4 = 16 feature maps.
an output with 1 feature map.
an output with (8x8)/(4x4) = 4 feature maps.
correctAnswer: an output with 2 feature maps.

question: Which of the following statements is/are true about virtual screening (VS)?
options: In VS, a trained neural network virtually searches through the whole chemical universe in order to find molecules with a specific bio-activity.
In VS, a trained neural network predicts the most relevant target molecule for a drug against a specific disease.
In VS, a trained neural network predicts the most likely conformation of large bio-molecules like proteins.
In VS, a trained neural network predicts whether a molecule in the data base is likely to bind/react with the target of interest.
correctAnswer: In VS, a trained neural network predicts whether a molecule in the data base is likely to bind/react with the target of interest.

question: You are given the derivative of the logistic function o' (x) and the following computation: y = o'(10@) * o'(10). Which of the following statements is/are correct?
options: y is very close to 10000.
y is very close to 0.
y is in the range (0, 1/4].
y is very close to 1/4.
correctAnswer: y is in the range (0, 1/4].
y is very close to 0.

question: Which of the following statements is/are true about tabular data?
options: Feature vectors can directly be obtained from the table.
Tabular data can be used in supervised as well as unsupervised learning.
It consists of samples that contain information on a variable/dynamic set of properties/features.
Each column corresponds to an individual sample.
correctAnswer: Tabular data can be used in supervised as well as unsupervised learning.
Feature vectors can directly be obtained from the table.

question: The CEC (constant error carousel) of an LSTM ...
options: ... is influenced by the introduction of the forget gate.
... is responsible for going from the old cell state to the new cell state.
... is an optional part.
... can mitigate the vanishing gradient problem.
correctAnswer: ... can mitigate the vanishing gradient problem.
... is influenced by the introduction of the forget gate.
... is responsible for going from the old cell state to the new cell state.

question: Which of the following statements is/are true about sequence data input and standard, feed-forward neural networks?
options: Sequences with variable lengths must be preprocessed before they can be an input to a feed-forward neural network.
Sequence data cannot be an input to a feed-forward neural network.
The relation of elements in the sequence is lost.
If the sequence length is equal, a feed-forward neural network behaves the same as a recurrent neural network.
correctAnswer: The relation of elements in the sequence is lost.
Sequences with variable lengths must be preprocessed before they can be an input to a feed-forward neural network.

question: Which of the following statements is/are true about the concept of an optimal policy?
options: High immediate rewards indicate an optimal policy.
It maximizes the sum of rewards.
There exists exactly one optimal policy.
The optimal policy may be obtained via Q-learning.
correctAnswer: It maximizes the sum of rewards.
The optimal policy may be obtained via Q-learning.

question: Which of the following statements is/are true about (deep) Q-learning?
options: Deep Q-learning is about approximating the Q-value function.
Q-learning can only be applied to small MDPs (Markov decision processes).
Q-learning is an implementation of reinforcement learning.
Deep Q-learning is often necessary for larger MDPs (Markov decision processes).
correctAnswer: Q-learning is an implementation of reinforcement learning.
Deep Q-learning is often necessary for larger MDPs (Markov decision processes).
Deep Q-learning is about approximating the Q-value function.

question: Which of the following statements is/are true about gating/gates in an LSTM?
options: Gating is the central part of the CEC.
Gates only depend on the current input.
Gating is used to control what to read/write/forget in memory.
Typically, sigmoid is used as gate function.
correctAnswer: Gating is used to control what to read/write/forget in memory.
Typically, sigmoid is used as gate function.

question: Which of the following statements is/are true about language models?
options: During training of an RNN language model, at each timestep, the encoder provides the probability distribution of the next word, where the probability distribution is defined over all the words in the dictionary.
Language modeling is the task of predicting a context given a word.

During training of an RNN language model, at each timestep, the decoder provides the probability distribution of the next word, where the probability distribution is defined over all the words in the dictionary.
Language modeling is the task of predicting a word given a context.
correctAnswer: Language modeling is the task of predicting a word given a context.

During training of an RNN language model, at each timestep, the decoder provides the probability distribution of the next word, where the probability distribution is defined over all the words in the dictionary.

question: Which of the following statements is/are true about recurrent neural networks?
options: They are suitable for processing sequences of fixed length.
They are suitable for processing sequences of variable length.
They incorporate information from the current timestep/position of a sequence.
They incorporate information from previous timesteps/positions of a sequence.
correctAnswer: They are suitable for processing sequences of variable length.
They incorporate information from the current timestep/position of a sequence.
They incorporate information from previous timesteps/positions of a sequence.
They are suitable for processing sequences of fixed length.

question: Which of the following statements is/are true about the one-to-many RNN type?
options: Given an input of length Tx > 1, the output/prediction length is Ty = 1.
Given an input of length Tx > 1, the output/prediction length is Ty > 1.
Given an input of length Tx = 1, the output/prediction length is Ty > 1.
Given an input of length Tx = 1, the output/prediction length is Ty = 1.
correctAnswer: Given an input of length Tx = 1, the output/prediction length is Ty > 1.

question: Which of the following statements is/are true about a policy in reinforcement learning?
options: A policy defines the agent's behavior.
The policy is the same as the value function.
An optimal policy maximizes the expected reward.
The policy is independent of the state.
correctAnswer: A policy defines the agent's behavior.
An optimal policy maximizes the expected reward.
